dialogues.text: I didn’t know it was she who wrote the verse. But then Judith and Hamnet were inseparable. I wasn’t allowed into their world.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why did she never tell me?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Out of loyalty to Hamnet I suppose. He wanted you to believe him brilliant in life. Why would he wish it any less in death?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It was cruel.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Cruel for her I think.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: For Judith?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Would you want to be denied credit for your verse? Have people think someone else writ them? Someone better educated?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No. No I shouldn’t like it at all.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Well look at them afresh. Celebrate your living daughter rather than your dead son. Perhaps Judith will finally smile again. Will is beginning to have some understanding of his insensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She burned them.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Burned them? Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Because I am a fool.  All Is True - Shooting Script 55. Will walks on. Susanna follows.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Father. Why do you write no more? Will still does not wish to answer this. But slowly, he tries.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: On the morning after the theatre burnt, I stood there, among the ruins, determined to begin again. To write another play. My greatest yet. To open another theatre. Even greater. He pauses. Collecting his thoughts. Susanna listens.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so I looked inside my self. Into my soul. I looked, as so often I had looked before. And this time... I found - Nothing. There was nothing there. I was as barren as the smoking ruins on which I stood. I was alone and frightened, and I realised this terrible thing. I realised that it just didn’t matter to me anymore. And there on that sad morning I knew that I would never write again. My soul was empty.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Your soul isn’t empty Father. Your soul has the whole world in it. But even if it was, I’m glad. For it’s brought you home. Will is very moved. 116 INT. JUDITH’S BED CHAMBER - NIGHT 116 Judith in her room. Will appears.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: You lost your son. Any man would mourn. A daughter is nothing. Destined only to become the property of another man. Or fade away.  All Is True - Shooting Script 56.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You mustn’t fade Judith. Why don’t you write again?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Father you know I can not write.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I could teach you. For a moment Judith is taken aback. This is such a potent resetting of their relationship. But it is too late.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I have no verse in me any more.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Because the wrong twin died.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No. Plague took him. Plague makes no judgements. It is just plague.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I wish a plague had taken me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Judith. Why do you hate yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I have stolen Hamnet from you twice. Once by surviving him, and now by taking your dream of him away.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You have given me a new dream. My beautiful daughter, the Poet.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: A woman can not be a poet. A woman is put upon this Earth for but one reason. I know my duty now. I will make amends for stealing Hamnet from you. I promise I will make amends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will digs. Anne joins him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I am glad Hamnet didn’t write the poems.  118 119 120 Anne looks at the garden. It is still pretty grim. smiles. All Is True - Shooting Script

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Glad?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know him better now. It is love not ambition that will blossom in this garden.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Well it had better because it doesn’t seem like much else has blossomed yet.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I am a poor gardener. It’s true. I found it much easier to create things with words.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Life’s like that. Would you like me to help? 57. She She smiles. He smiles. Together they begin to work on the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne gets ready for bed. Will appears.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Goodnight my love.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Stay Will. For comfort. With me. In our second best bed. Will smiles. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judith is approaching Quiney’s wine shop. EXT. HALL’S CROFT - DAY Anne is approaching Susanna’s house. She knocks Susanna answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Susanna. There is something I should like your help with. 118 119 120 at the door.  All Is True - Shooting Script 58. 121 INT. QUINEY’S WINE SHOP - DAY 121 Judith enters. She closes the door and stares at Quiney.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I will take that glass of Rhennish wine with you Tom Quiney. 122 INT. HALL’S CROFT - EVENING 122 Susanna and John Hall. She stitching, he with his bible.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Your sister has been seen in Thomas Quiney’s shop.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Quiney supplies wine to my father’s house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: She was not ordering wine. She was drinking it. With Quiney. She was inside for half an hour or more.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Is this the faith your Puritan brothers practise? Spying on women?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: They were quite public in their merry making. They went later together to the tavern.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: If Judith is reaching for a little happiness then I am glad of it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Sinning will not make her happy.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Really? Then let us hope it makes her unhappiness a little more bearable.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: That is a wicked thing to say. Remember your scripture.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: What I remember is a little girl who smiled a lot. I should like to see what that smile looks like on the woman that girl became.  123 124 125 All Is True - Shooting Script 59.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: A reputation once lost can not be refound.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Mine was.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Yours was not lost! It was defamed by a convicted drunkard and suspected Papist. Judith must drop this Quiney. He is debauched.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: If only those without sin were allowed to marry, there would be precious few weddings. INT. QUINEY’S WINE SHOP - EVENING 123 Quiney and Judith kissing.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: You know that I am not a good man. There have been women. Many women.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I have seen too little of life. You’ve seen too much. Between us perhaps we may begin again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hustle and bustle of a tiny market town. Quiney and Judith walk together. She is still sombre and serious but buys her a piece of fruit from a stall, maybe even juggle some? He wins a smile. The first we have seen! Margaret Wheeler is watching. She is both sad and bitter. Quiney sees her but manages to prevent Judith doing so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Anne work together in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: He has a good business with his wine and tobacco shop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And people will always want those.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Unless John and his Puritan friends have their way.  126 All Is True - Shooting Script 60.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I've known the Quiney family all my life. They can be a wild and merry crew, but good hearted. Will glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poor lodging in a near by village. Quiney is visiting. Margaret Wheeler (who we saw him with at the church). She sits with her parents.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: I can not see you anymore Margaret I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Because of Judith Shakespeare?

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: I never made you promise Margaret you know that. If we sinned we sinned together. Margaret’s father speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET'S FATHER
dialogues.text: She’s with child. This is a big blow.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: Can you be sure it’s mine? Margaret reddens, perhaps she can’t be sure. Her father i though and takes up a hatchet from the fire side.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET'S FATHER
dialogues.text: You dare ask it? Dare again! The Father is intimidating, but Quiney holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: Margaret has many friends at the tavern.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I’m certain... I think... I believe it’s yours Tom. Honestly I do. Quiney is not a bad man. He and Margaret have been friend

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: I have a wine shop. My family is prosperous. You will always have money for the child, always. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 128 All Is True - Shooting Script 61.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And for your comfort too, a small dowry that you might find a husband who will take your child as his own. Margaret's father puts down his axe.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope that in return you will not name me as the father. Margaret is sad but she knows it’s the best deal she’1l g Her father knows this also. He nods grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hall enters. He approaches the Landlady.

dialogues.speaker: STRATFORD LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Well well. Doctor Hall. I did not look to see you in the Tavern. Has all your preachifying given you a thirst?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: A cup of water if you please.

dialogues.speaker: STRATFORD LANDLADY
dialogues.text: I shall charge you pottage. There is water at the pump. John Hall puts a coin down.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Tom Quiney the Vintner drinks here does he not?

dialogues.speaker: STRATFORD LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Since he was a boy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: I would have you tell me what company he has kept of late. What female company. Hall puts another couple of coins down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW PLACE
dialogues.text: Will in his study. A serving girl shows in his lawyer Fra Collins. Will is a feeling happy.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Francis Collins! Come in! Come in! You'll take some wine? Maria! A jug of wine if you please.  All Is True - Shooting Script 62.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I am relived to see you in such high spirits Will. When a man sends for his lawyer it is not always so.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Judith’s getting married!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: No! Congratulations! It was a crime that such a pretty girl remained unwed.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well crime no longer! And thus would I amend my Will to include my new Son in Law Tom Quiney.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Quiney is it? Wine and tobacco. Good trade.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Can’t think of better. Also we must of course make provision for his and Judith’s male issue. The wine arrives. Will fills their glasses for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My grandsons!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Many of them! They drink. Will has a mischievous glint in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And I wish also to leave something for Anne.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Anne? If she survives you she will have a third by law.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh she’1ll survive me. I have little doubt of that. She’s years older and ten times tougher. But I don’t mean money! She’1ll have more of that than she can spend. I had in mind a piece of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Furniture? But Anne will live here and have the use of every stick.  130 131 132 133 All Is True - Shooting Script 63.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: A specific piece of furniture. Which when it is no longer ours must be hers. And I hope that in it will she smile and think of me. Will drinks happily. Francis shrugs and gets papers and p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congregation gathers. A merry scene as townsfolk go i the church. Quiney arrives with his brother, there is muc back slapping as they make their way in. Margaret Wheeler and her parents attend. She is heavily pregnant and ashamed that all pity her unmarried conditio Her father’s face shows angry defiance. INT. HOLY TRINITY CHURCH —- MORNING 131 Quiney enters. He sees that amongst the happy faces Marga sits grimly and tearfully at the back with her mother and father. Quiney catches Margaret's eye but he can not read face. Now Susanna and John Hall enter, John Hall sees Margaret and note that Quiney is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Will arrives with Judith. A happy morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vicar Edward Woolmer is officiating over the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER
dialogues.text: Before I pronounce you man and wife I must ask this congregation does any know of any reason why these two should not wed. This is a tense moment for Quiney. His eyes flick to Margaret, her face a mask, her father shifts in his pew, he speak? Will John Hall? Hall is watching intently. None speak. The Vicar continues and completes the service

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I now pronounce you man and wife. Judith turns for a moment to her father. She smiles at hi she is doing this for him but she is happy. She turns bac Quiney and embraces him  135 136 137 All Is True - Shooting Script 64. CARD: On the tenth of February 1616 at Holy Trinity Churc Stratford Upon Avon, Judith Shakespeare then aged 31, mar Thomas Quiney, the local Vintner and tobacconist whom she known all her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The happy throng emerge. Margaret (her head bowed in sham over her very pregnant body) slips away with her parents. John Hall follows them.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW PLACE
dialogues.text: The wedding feast. A great cheering. This is a happy and joyous affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hall is confronting Margaret and her parents.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Who is the father girl?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I will not tell. John Hall glances at the well stocked shelves. Wine. Food pile of what are clearly new blankets and sheets.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: This house is blessed with a goodly abundance. Your silence has been bought. Margaret and her parents stare defiance at the two purita

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW PLACE
dialogues.text: Will is making a speech to the rapt crowd

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: «++. One son in law owns a wine shop the other one wants to close it. (laughter) A happy balance I think, balance in nature always appealed to me and a happy balance is what I feel now at this wonderful feast. You all know the Shakespeare’s. You knew my father when he was your Mayor, and you also knew him in less happy times...  All Is True - Shooting Script 65. A reveller calls out cheekily.

dialogues.speaker: O/S REVELLER
dialogues.text: He certainly knew the price of wool!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Of course he did! He made it up himself! Laughter and some ‘woos’. Will is being pretty honest.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know that sometimes we Shakespeare’s have been our own worst enemies. And sometimes we have had the worst of enemies. Will looks at Susanna who gives him a little smile. Anoth voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: 0/S VOICE
dialogues.text: If ever John Lane shows his face around here again he’1ll have the nose cut off it! All cheer at that.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We have had our ups and downs but I flatter myself that after my father’s shall we say ‘creative’ approach to matters financial I have brought some small credit to my home town. Another cheer and another voice shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: O/S VOICE
dialogues.text: The world will know of Stratford On Avon because of you sir! More cheers.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And although I no longer have a son... and show me a family in this town that has not lost at least one child... I have two beautiful daughters. So perhaps one day I shall have a grandson. Susanna is embarrassed by this. Judith smiles at Quiney.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For that I look to you Tom and you also John! Be about your business both of you!  138 139 All Is True - Shooting Script 66. Much good natured cheering. Quiney raises his mug. Hall d his best to produce a grim smile.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For family is everything and today, I could not be more proud of mine. More cheers. There are calls for “the Groom”. Quiney stan

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: My friends. I have known Judith all my life. And I have loved her near as long. I remember her as a happy child and I remember the shadow that fell on her when she lost that other half of herself. That twin soul with whom she entered this world. I have asked her for her hand many times across the years. I don’t know what it was that finally caused her to say yes, all I can say is that I am happy for it and my dearest hope on this our wedding day is that I can bring into Judith’s life a little of the happiness that has forsaken her for so long. Judith is touched. Anne and Will too. All cheer. INT. JUDITH AND QUINEY’S BED CHAMBER - NIGHT 138 It is their wedding night. They stand before each other.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I saw Margaret Wheeler in the Church today Tom.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: I know it Judith and I have confessed all to you. I can not undo what is done. All I can say is that her child and she will not want. They embrace and begin to make love. CARD: Shortly after their wedding Judith and Tom Quiney conceived a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot. Hustle and bustle of a market town. Judith and Quiney walk hand in hand. They are happy.  140 141 142 143 144 All Is True - Shooting Script 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is in labour. It’s a bad one. She’s screaming. H mother is trying to help but gives up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: The child is breech.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET'S FATHER
dialogues.text: We must send for Doctor Hall. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - DAY 141 Quiney and Judith are visiting Will and Anne.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: It’s very early Father but I believe I am.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh my sweet girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is screaming, the baby is not coming. Dr Hall is doing what he can but he knows it’s desperate. He takes t grim forceps from his bag. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - DAY 143 Susanna has joined the family gathering.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Sister. I am truly happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Where is John? He should be here.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: He was called out... toa confinement. Judith and Quiney know who that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret's screams reach a terrible crescendo. Then silen Her writhing body falls still. All know immediately that is gone. John Hall works feverishly at the limp body but no avail.  145 146 All Is True - Shooting Script 68.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: The child has departed with it’s mother. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - DAY 145 A merry conversation is in progress. Judith and Quiney laughing with Will and Anne. Even Susanna laughs merrily. John Hall enters. Perhaps still blood splattered. Clearly something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: Quiney. Margaret Wheeler has died in childbirth along with her baby. The child has no name. It will not enter heaven without one. Quiney knows what he must do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret's parents are burying their daughter and grandch Tom Quiney and Judith are also there and stand some way apart. Judith with her hand on her own belly lost ina confusion of thoughts. The service ends. The parents turn to walk away. They pau before Quiney and Judith.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Wheeler. Mrs. Wheeler. I’m so sorry. CARD: Margaret Wheeler, former lover to Thomas Quiney was buried with her child on 16th March 1616. CARD: On 25th of March 1616 Shakespeare once more amended Will, striking out provisions made for his new son in law

dialogues.speaker: INT NEW PLACE DAY
dialogues.text: Will has signed and lays down his pen. He looks so sad. F once John Hall is moved.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HALL
dialogues.text: I take no pleasure in Judith’s distress Father in Law. Or yours. It grieves me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know that. John.  149 150 All Is True - Shooting Script 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bawdy court is assembling. Pious, grim figures. CARD: On March 26th 1616 Tom Quiney was tried before the Bawdy Court in the same church in which he had been marri six weeks earlier. He made a full confession. Thomas Quiney stands before the Court and congregation.

dialogues.speaker: QUINEY
dialogues.text: I got her with child. It was carnal copulation out of wedlock and I am sorry for it. Sorry for the agony it has caused to her family and sorry for the shame I have brought on mine.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER
dialogues.text: The sentence of the court is that you shall parade yourself in open penance, clad only in a white sheet for three Sundays before this congregation. Will feels once more the weight of shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is walking in the High Street, still in smart clothe but looking older and sadder. He is no longer greeted wit respect, instead he gets smirks or looks of sympathy, he catches people pointing. Sir Thomas Lucy walks by.

dialogues.speaker: SIR THOMAS
dialogues.text: Well well Mr. Shakespeare. How very unfortunate. Seems your daughter’s wedding was rushed for a reason. Like your own eh? The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree. Damn me you Shakespeare’s are a scandalous lot eh? Perhaps being an illiterate farm girl your wife was unable to teach your girls morals. Well well. Must be getting on. Can’t loll about thinking pretty thoughts all day like you poets. I must to business. Lucy is about to walk on. Will stops him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Business Sir Thomas?  All Is True - Shooting Script 69A.

dialogues.speaker: SIR THOMAS
dialogues.text: Yes yes business. A large estate like Charlecote Manor doesn’t run itself ye’ know.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh I thought you meant a real business. Like building, owning and operating London’s largest theatre for instance. Sir Thomas about to speak but Will ploughs on.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actors, carpenters, seamstresses, crew. Bribes to pay, security to mount, politics to navigate. Fifteen hundred paying public each afternoon, to be fed, watered, and given a spectacle which must be ever greater than the last. 170 Royal performances for our Queen and our king. Have you ever considered the cost and logistics of mounting the Battle of Shrewsbury in the banqueting hall at Hampton Court? Please don’t. It would make you very, very tired. And yet Sir Thomas, in all the years I ran my vast, complex and spectacularly successful business I also did find time to think and write down those pretty thoughts you mentioned, which in my experience brought immense pleasure to those seeking respite from this vale of tears, and without which the whole thing would have been as pointless as..? Well, as pointless as you Sir Thomas. Will about to leave but then has a final thought.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And since you brought her up, my wife Anne has more wisdom and decency in her daily shit than you have in your entire body. Lucy is a little shaken but walks on with dignity. Will c after him.  151 152 153 154 All Is True - Shooting Script 70.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish I had poached your bloody deer! Will walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. Anne works alone. The garden is blooming but Anne is sad for Will seems to have forsaken it. Will emerges from the house

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Will you work with me a while Husband? You could put some beer about for the slugs.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: By the look of things Anne you do better without me. I think I shall walk a little. He heads for the garden gate. Then pauses.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: She did it for you Will. You wanted a grandson. She returns to her digging. Will walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits watching the children play. Once more he thinks sees the boy. Once more when he looks again the boy has g Something occurs to Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is walking towards the church. He pauses at the graveyard wall. Will enters and walks to his son's grave. The Stone reads “Hamnet Shakespeare. 1585 to 1596”. He stands in contemplation. Then walks into the church. INT. HOLY TRINITY CHURCH —- MORNING 154 Will walks through the empty church. He sits in a pew wit his thoughts. The vicar enters.  155 All Is True - Shooting Script 71.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Shakespeare. In church and it isn’t Sunday? Dare I hope that you are seeking to know God a little better?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: People who claim to know God feel entitled to speak for him. I prefer to maintain a respectful distance. Which I imagine God appreciates. May I see the Church register?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chancery. Will sits at the desk. Woolmer busies himse with the registers.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER
dialogues.text: You did not attend the funeral? The question is a painful one.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I was travelling home. The news arrived in London after I had left. By the time I arrived he lay in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD WOOLMER
dialogues.text: It was summer. No corpse remains unburied long. Particularly a plague corpse. Here is the page. August 1596. Will looks at the entry for Hamnet’s death. The Year 1596 His eye moves up and down the column. From the deaths recorded in 1596 to those in 95 and then 97. Will traces his finger across the Hamnet’s entry. Almost trying to touch the boy. Will is remembering...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'd brought him a pen knife. A special one with a folding blade. His name engraved upon the handle. (beat) How he would have loved that knife. Will takes out the knife which is old now, and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I keep it with me still... There is a pot of quills on the desk. Will takes one.  159 All Is True - Shooting Script 72.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Woolmer nods. Will begins to cut the quill.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And whenever I cut a new nib, I imagine that my hand is his hand. Grown to be a man... Will watches his hand as he cuts at the quill.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trimming his quill with the knife his father gave him - on that joyful home coming long ago. Will has cut a beautiful nib. He dips it in ink.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when I dip the ink and mark the page, it’s still his hand I see and the words that I write are his. He writes a word or two.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then I tell myself that it isn’t me who thinks of him at all, but that I am dead, while Hamnet lives, and thinks of me. Will lays down the quill and folds the knife away. Edward Woolmer glances down at the page Will has written on. He wrote “Hamnet Shakespeare”.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People often ask how I have writ so much. How I found the energy and dedication to sit alone at my desk writing play after play after play. The answer's simple, I was always in the company of my son. He gives way to grief. Edward Woolmer stand silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will has returned to Hamnet’s grave. He reads the inscrip again. Year of death 1596. Will glances at the other graves close by, the years of d 1594, 1597, 1597, 1598. Will is thinking.  160 162 163 164 All Is True - Shooting Script 73. HALL’S CROFT - DAY 160 Will has gone to talk with Susanna.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: It began and ended so quickly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It is always so with the plague.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: The four of us had supped that night. We were usually a merry crowd we four at table but that night I recall Hamnet was quiet. The illness already in his system no doubt. Judith teased him as she always did but that night could win no smile in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it is a flashback we see Anne wake with a start. She heard Judith’s voice shout “Hamnet!” Susanna’s voice over continues to describe the scene.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mother told me she was awoken that night by Judith’s cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in flash back. Anne enters the children’s room. Fir she sees Judith crying in fear. Judith points to Hamnet w he lies already becoming plague ridden.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mother bid Hamnet come at once with her to save Judith from infection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in flashback. Anne is leading the stricken boy to t woods.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She knew already that Hamnet could not survive and so did her best to isolate him from all but herself. But Judith disobeyed and followed. Judith is following Anne and Hamnet.  All Is True - Shooting Script 74.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was a warm night. The air was sweet and Hamnet begged to be taken to his favourite place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamnet, now with pustules fully breaking out lies on the lit grass beside the water. He screams in fear and pain.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They nursed him through the night with cool water from the brook and prayer. Mother did as best she could to keep Judith and herself from contact with his sores and by God's mercy neither was infected. Dawn now. Hamnet dies.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He left them as the Sun rose. Mother sent Judith for blankets and thread to make a shroud. Cross fade. Anne has stitched blankets around the corpse, completely containing it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When the plague is involved it’s best not to linger too long saying goodbye. When I awoke she’d sent for the graves-men. Hamnet was already in his coffin. 167 INT. HALL’S CROFT - DAY 167 Back in the present. Susanna still with Will.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Judith never smiled again. Will is thinking. He sees greater tragedy in his mind eve than that which has been described. 168 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 168 Later Will and Anne before the fire. Judith enters.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: You sent for me Father?  All Is True - Shooting Script 75.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes Judith. Thank you for coming. Your new home is comfortable I hope?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: There’s much to do but my husband is working hard. He is a good man despite the shame he brought us. Will swallows. It’s still a painful memory.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I visited Hamnet’s grave today. I read his name in the Parish Register.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I am glad of it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Anne I have known the plague. Many times in London did it strike and all the theatres must be closed. Neither Anne or Judith reply.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, I have known the plague. And I was thinking today that Black Death is a scythe it is not a dagger.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Never once did I see it strike a single person, and then depart. Anne and Judith remain silent. Will is wrestling with a question he does not want to ask.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did Hamnet die? Neither Anne nor Judith show any emotion. But now we see tear rolling from Judith’s expressionless eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His death is recorded in the Parish register but with no mention of the cause.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Plague husband. The priest pronounced it at his funeral.  169 170 All Is True - Shooting Script 76.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Because that is what you told him. And also what no doubt you told the grave’s men when they arrived in the greenwood to find him stitched up in his shroud. In all their minds a remembered scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamnet’s shrouded corpse lies in the grass, a sad bundle. Little Judith is being comforted by Anne. Two Grave’s men have arrived. Heavily cloaked men wearing the horrible be nosed masks used to ward off plague. They have a great sh They approach the bundled corpse warily. Like hook beaked vultures gathering round carrion. They lift it quickly an fearfully, perhaps even manipulating it with hooked poles Nobody wants to contact with a plaque victim any longer t necessary. They dump it on the sheet and drag the corpse bundle away. CARD: Hamnet Shakespeare died on or around the 9th of Aug 1596 and was buried on the 11th. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 170 We are back in the moment, Will is still quietly question Anne.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: When I look at other graves around about Hamnet’s and at his name in the register. I see that no scythe swung through this town in the summer of 1596. Five children only were taken and three of those were new born’s. Not like in other plague years. Why in 1597 even dozens were cut down. (beat) Wife. How did Hamnet die?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He died of plague. Will stares hard at Anne, his heart in torment. She retur his stare with stony defiance. Then Judith speaks. Slowly scarcely with emotion. Her eyes distant, her voice tonele

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I woke Mother in the night with my cry.  171 172 173 174 All Is True - Shooting Script 77. Once more we see the scene in flashback. This time descri by Judith in Voice Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again in flashback we see Anne wake with a start. She has heard Judith’s voice shout “Hamnet!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in flash back. Anne enters the children’s room. Fir she sees Judith crying in fear. Judith points but this ti to an empty place in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hamnet’s bed was empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in flashback. Anne rushing through the wood.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mother searched the house and then thought of the Greenwood Pond that was his favourite place even though he couldn’t swim and would never go in the water. Judith emerges from the house and follows Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne approaches the water with Judith behind her. They wa to the edge and now, in the Moonlight they see Hamnet, de floating like Ophelia. He is surrounded not by lilies but torn pages of paper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Around him, torn and shredded floated the final verses I had conjured and which he had writ. The ones prepared for your return. Anne moves towards the water to get Hamnet’s corpse.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mother sent me for blankets and thread. So that none would know how Hamnet died.  All Is True - Shooting Script 78. 176 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 176 Back in the present Judith has told her story. Anne speak with hollow firmness.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: That’s your story Judith and you have carried it’s burden ever since. But I say he died of plague. The vicar spake it at his grave and God accepts it. Millions have died of it and Hamnet entered Heaven amongst that host. Jesus would not have denied him his place whatever Judith thinks we saw. Will is too broken to speak. Instead Judith cries out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Of course he’s in Heaven! Hamnet didn’t kill himself, he only threw himself upon the water. It was I that caused it. I killed him! I killed my brother!

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No Judith! It isn’t so! Judith turns to Will, utterly distraught.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: He wanted to please you so much. All he cared about was your love and all you cared about was him! I was jealous... I was jealous... Hamnet went to school. I helped in the kitchen because I was a girl. I wanted your approval too. I wanted your love... Will is numb.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I told him I would tell you! That this time you would know which twin had writ the verse. I didn’t mean it! I wouldn’t have done it. I loved him. But he believed me... He couldn't face your disappointment. Judith sobs in abject misery. Anne comforts Judith.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He died of plague Judith. God accepts that. It was only a little lie. He was only a little boy. Will gets up unsteadily, puts on his cloak and leaves.  177 178 All Is True - Shooting Script 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wild night. Will stumbles through the woods. He calls o

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hamnet! He thinks he sees the Boy again. Somewhere in the woods. boy runs. Will crashes after him. Rain lashing down. Will has arrived at the pond. He stares at he still Moon water. Almost delirious he grabs at a rock and puts it in shirt. Gathering another he wades into the water. When it deep enough he plunges under. The rocks aren’t heavy enough. He surfaces but plunges ag Then he sees the boy standing on the bank. The boy smiles. Will stops. He stands waste deep in the water.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You finished it. Will doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My story’s done. Go home now. I can rest. Will reaches out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hamnet please. Stay a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: We are such stuff As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep. The boy is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few people are up and about. Milk churns are being cart Bread baked. Will walks home through the town, a filthy a disheveled figure, soaked through. A stark contrast to th proud man in his fine clothes. A few faces turn.  179 180 All Is True - Shooting Script 80. EXT. NEW PLACE —- MORNING 179 Will arrives home, a sorry, shivering figure. Anne opens door to him. She looks on him with pity and with love. Wi seems so diminished.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I think perhaps I have caught a little chill. CARD: In April 1616 Shakespeare was visited by his friend rival Ben Jonson INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S HALL —- NIGHT 180 Will, wrapped in rugs and seeming rather ill is dining wi Jonson.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: Christ Will! You have had a time of it! Both daughters caught up in scandals. Good for them!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. So far retirement hasn't exactly brought me the peace I’d hoped for. Jonson sups deep. He is a confident, bold, opinionated ma but also astute and he loves Will.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: In my experience Will no one ever gets what they hope for. But they do tend to get what they deserve.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You think I got what I deserve?

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: Not all of it perhaps but something certainly. You lost a son. No man deserves that but most men suffer it. I myself have lost a daughter and a son.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know my friend.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: But you have two daughters still, who love you and a wife to share your bed. I have none of that. Mine own Anne despises me.  All Is True - Shooting Script 81.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well you publicly insult her and call her ‘shrew’. Can you blame her?

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: I didn’t say she had no cause only that she does. Like your Anne (wife?). She loves William Shakespeare. But she won’t put up with the monster. You tell me that Southampton says you've lived a little life. What an arse! You have conquered England and returned victorious to the bosom of your family? Is that little?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Perhaps the second part.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: The second part is the best part! You made it home Will. How many other conquerors can say as much? What poets? Anyone can die alone and despised. Marlowe was murdered and no one can agree on which of his many enemies did it, Greene died in poverty, estranged from all who knew him. Kyd the same. No one knows how Tom Nashe died but if his filthy dildo poem’s are anything to go by it wasn’t in the bosom of his family. Will laughs which brings on a coughing fit.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I? Well while I am not dead I may soon be for I am out of favour with the king and none will speak for me. But you Will. You made it home. Any of us might wish we had half your ‘littleness’.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Well, perhaps put like that.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: You have kept your friends too, even me and I am a waspish fellow. Hemming and Condell are feverishly seeking out your scripts intent that all should be published and your genius be preserved down the ages. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All Is True - Shooting Script 81A.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Name another writer the bloody actors have revered like that? Yes we tease you Will. I’ve done it myself. A lot. ‘Not without right’.  180c 181 All Is True - Shooting Script 82. Will puts a bit of mustard on his ham in salute.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Or as you kindly put it publicly, “Not without Mustard”

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: But you have your family and your friends, a full fire and a full belly. And oh, by the way you have written the greatest body of plays that ever were or will be. Damn your eyes you bastard! Yes my friend, I think you got what you deserved. Will is much moved by all of this.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Ben. I have an idea. EXT. JUDITH'’S CHAMBER WINDOW- NIGHT 180c Will and Jonson outside on the street.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Judith!

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Shhh! Don’t wake your husband.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We're going to the pub. Wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW PLACE
dialogues.text: Will and Jonson both drunk have got a ladder and Jonson a are setting it beneath Will’s Coat of Arms. Judith stops them.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: You’re both too drunk for ladders. Just hold the bottom. The pregnant Judith begins to climb.  182 183 All Is True - Shooting Script 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two playwrights and Judith are making their way tipsi up the street carrying the Coat of Arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter and to everyone’s astonishment plonk it on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The Shakespeare Coat of Arms. It cost me twenty quid. Who wants it for nothing? General surprise. Judith smiles. She understands what thi means to Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang it above the bar if you wish for I have no more need of it. You all know me anyway! I’m the son of a dodgy trader and my wife was three months knocked up when I took her to the altar. One of my girls married a carnal copulator no offense Jude...

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: None taken Father, he did tell the entire town.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And the other one married a Puritan.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Which personally I think is worse!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Here here!

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: Bloody right!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Some people think I poached one of Lucy’s stags which I didn’t but I wish I had.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: And never mind stags anyway you once stole an entire theatre.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Very true.  183a 184 All Is True - Shooting Script 84.

dialogues.speaker: JONSON
dialogues.text: I was there!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I worked too hard, drank too little and worried too much about what arseholes like you lot thought of me. Good natured cheers.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took my extremely long suffering wife for granted, neglected my beautiful, clever daughters. He looks at Judith who returns his smile.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And expected too much of my beloved son. Apart from all that, I wrote 37 plays, some of which I admit were rather long but all of which are works of absolute genius. Except possibly The Two Gentlemen of Verona.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is William Shakespeare. And I am not a gentleman. All cheer. Judith hugs Will. The party begins. EXT NEW PLACE DAWN 183a A crisp spring morning. INT. ANNES’S BEDROOM - MORNING 184 Will lies in bed. He’s weak and ill. The chill is worse. dying. Anne, Judith and Sue enter. Judith now showing her pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Father. It’s a special day. And Mother and Sue have prepared a special present. Susanna takes a document and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Goodness. What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Its our marriage licence Will. 34 years ago I put my mark to it.  185 All Is True - Shooting Script 85.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: And now... There is a little bureau, Susanna produces quill and ink. Anne sits and with great care signs the licence.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Anne.... Shakespeare. Will smiles and looks at the licence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You have a beautiful hand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Sue is teaching me also and by the time you are better I shall have written you a poem. Will smiles with deep and special pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You will need a pen knife then. This is yours. Will takes Hamnet’s knife from his pocket and gives it he

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: And what should you like to do today Father? On this special day? He smiles. He is at peace.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows... As the poem continues in voice over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is beautiful now, a graphic maze garden of beautifully arranged grasses. A knot garden of charm and symmetry. Th ladies lead Will to a seat and gather around him while li Elizabeth plays. Standing apart but also included are Hal and Quiney.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows, Quite overcanopied with luscious woodbine, With sweet musk roses and with eglantine. There sleeps Titania sometime of the night, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 186 All Is True - Shooting Script 86.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight. CARD: William Shakespeare died on 23th April 1616 in the where he was born. It was his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Will’s funeral. Music. A sombre, respectful congregation. Now Anne, Judith and Susanna stand together the dais. They have a piece of paper. First Anne reads, i a little faltering but loud and proud.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Fear no more the heat o the sun. Judith reads the second line. Also falteringly. It is heartbreakingly poignant, Anne and Judith finally beginni to read Will’s poetry.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Nor the furious winters rages Now Susanna takes over. She of course reads with confiden and beautiful clarity.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Thou thy worldy task hast done, Home art gone, and ta’en thy wages Golden lads and girls all must As chimney sweepers come to dust As the verses continue, we move away down the church, and fade to black. A final card William Shakespeare, 1564 - 1616, writer. CARD: Anne Died 9 years later. Will had bequeathed her his second best bed. Judith Quiney had three boys. All died young. Elizabeth Hall, Susanna’s only child married twice but ha children. She died aged 61, the last of Shakespeare’s line.
